title: football star smacked girlfriend face
story: NewsFootball star 'smacked girlfriend in the face for throwing away out of date steak'Striker Christian Nade, 33, who used to play for Hearts, denies six domestic abuse charges&nbspShareByRory Cassidy06:28, 19 JUN 2018Updated06:54, 19 JUN 2018NewsChristian Nade playing for current team Dumbarton in 2016 (Image: JEFF HOLMES/JSHPIX.CO 07802 6100)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA footballer backhanded his ex-girlfriend in the face because she threw out a steak that was out of date, a court heard. Christian Nade, who used to play for SPL team Hearts, is accused of assaulting Laura Kennedy and subjecting her to domestic abuse while she mourned her grandmother's death.  The 28-year-old Kennedy told the court he also hit her with a boxed toy car she was due to give a child as a Christmas gift and assaulted her on a third occasion because she threw away a sauce he had made at the flat they shared in Renfrew, reports the Daily Record .  Laura, a skin specialist, rubbished claims she lashed out at Nade on each occasion after finding out he had been cheating on her and that he had actually been acting in self-defence to stop her from hitting him.  Nade, 33, who went on trial at Paisley Sheriff Court yesterday, denies six charges relating to incidents between December last year and March. Laura, niece of Dumbarton assistant manager and former Rangers star Ian Durrant, told the court that Nade first struck her on December 5 after a row about a steak that had been in their fridge for so long it was going green. The blonde mum, who said she was 5ft 7in and weighs 9st, explained: “I went to the police about Christian lifting his hands to me – I wanted to report it. “I remember it was the start of December because my gran had just passed away. “The first time was because I had thrown out food from the fridge and because I never apologised, he hit me. “There was an out-of-date steak in the fridge and I threw it out. “He hit me in the face with the back of his hand. It was the right side of my face – it was my cheek and my ear. “I had a red mark on my face.”

title: gay pride manchester events parade
story: NewsPride Manchester 2018: Dates, key events and parade times for this year's celebration'sHeading to Manchester for Pride this month? Here's all the info you'll need for a brilliant weekend including where to stay and what to see&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByHarriet FlookContent Commercialisation Editor12:47, 19 JUN 2018NewsAre you looking forward to Manchester Pride this year? (Image: Rex)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Manchester Pride Festival is one of the biggest Pride events in UK. This year, it take place in the city from 24 August to 27 August. Manchester Pride campaigns for the advancement of LGBT+ equality celebrates LGBT+ life and creates opportunities that engage LGBT+ people so that they can thrive.   The event isn't restricted to the LGBTQ+ community too, and is frequently celebrated as one of the most inclusive events in the world. So if you're thinking of attending here's all the information you need for a weekend you'll never forget.   What are the dates of Manchester Pride? Manchester Pride starts on 24 August and will continue until 27 August 2017, with the parade held on 25 August. There is also a candlelight vigil on the 27 August in Sackville Gardens.   What's on at Manchester Pride?  The Manchester Pride Festival is run by Manchester Pride (the charity) and is made up of the Candlelit Vigil, the Parade and Suberbia Weekend, all of which are free. The only event people need tickets for is The Big Weekend, which are the performances from Rita Ora, Jake Shear etc. You can get tickets here.  You can find out more about other events around Manchester Pride here.  When is the parade? The parade takes place on the 25th, with starting times to be confirmed soon. The parade's theme is 'The Circus of Acceptance'. Find more information and FAQ's here. Where can I stay? There are a number of hotel options available for your stay in Manchester. Travelodge rooms start from &pound35 and there are 23 hotels close to the city centre, so there's plenty of choice. Bigger groups may find it cheaper to stay in an AirBnB or TripAdvisor recommended rental property .  If you're looking for a cheaper option, there loads of hostels dotted around Manchester too Manchester, we recommend Hatters and YHA, but there's plenty on Hostelworld which offer award-winning service and premium facilities - without the huge price tag.  How do I get to Manchester? There are plenty of affordable options if you're planning to travel into Manchester via coach or train. If you book in advance National Express offer coach fares from just &pound5 one-way. If you are travelling via train book in advance to save money - try the Trainline's Best Fare Finder or book using Virgin Train's website for the cheapest fares.

title: hero neighbours capture suspected burglar
story: NewsHero neighbours capture suspected burglar on 'roof looking in windows' and frogmarch him down street to waiting policeThe man spent several hours on a roof on Saturday morning before allegedly making a run for it and being caught in a headlock by a homeowner's son&nbspShareByJamie Waller08:36, 19 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA team of hero neighbours caught a suspected burglar and frogmarched him into the hands of police following a three-hour standoff. The man spent several hours on a roof on Saturday morning after residents spotted him looking in their first-floor windows. Once he made a break for it, the homeowner's son leaped over a six-foot fence and put the man in a headlock.  Other members of the community in Grimsby then marched him back to police, Grimsby Live reported.  Howard Clough said: My wife woke me up to tell me there was someone on our kitchen roof who had been trying the windows. We've got some young kids so it was very worrying.  The man, who was described as in his late 20s, refused to come down from the ground-floor roof of the house even after the police arrived. Howard's son Liam and several other residents gathered around, but the man refused to budge. Residents believe the man had been on another roof on the street at 6am that morning, but that wasn't reported to police. Someone down the road saw him looking into bedrooms about 6am. One person's son asked his dad: Why is there a man looking in my window?' according to Mr Clough. The man's story allegedly constantly changed - at first, he told residents he was getting a football off the roof and later said he was being chased by six men and couldn't get down because he was scared. Police arrived on the scene shortly after being alerted to the incident.  We tried to keep him calm and talk him into getting down. One person kept offering him a lighter to persuade him, but he wouldn't do it, Howard said. After several hours, Howard's neighbour Lee lost patience and climbed out onto his own kitchen roof, which is connected to the other ones on the road. The man jumped down and started garden-hopping fences, pursued by the residents. My son Liam was the fastest - he managed to get to the end of the street, where the man had hopped over a six-foot fence. Liam jumped through a patch of the nettles without even looking, and vaulted straight over it after him, Howard said. We ran around and found Liam had got the man in a headlock. We were able to walk him back over to the police, who arrested him.

title: hyde park floating barrels look
story: NewsHyde Park floating barrels that look like "giant Donkey Kong thing" confuse Londoners - but are actually ARTWeighing around 600 tonnes and using 7,506 barrels, it's actually a new art installation called ‘The London Mastaba’ from Bulgarian artist Christo Vladimirov Javacheff&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary12:44, 19 JUN 2018NewsThirty two anchors hold the huge structure in place (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCommuters have been left very confused by this stack of 7,506 floating barrels in London's Hyde Park. The towering stack appeared to pop up almost overnight as it was completed in time for early-risers strolling through the park to admire this morning - and most were stumped as to what they could be. One Twitter user, Toby Gilham, posted: There's a giant Donkey Kong thing going off in Hyde Park at the moment... Weighing around 600 tonnes, the multi-coloured barrels are actually the brainchild of artist Christo Vladimirov Javacheff. Officially named 'The London Mastaba', the enormous artwork measures 20m high, 30m wide and 40m long - with 32 anchors holding the structure in place. Bulgarian-born artist Christo said: For three months, The London Mastaba will be a part of Hyde Park's environment in the centre of London.   Banksy print 'Trolley Hunters' stolen from art exhibition in Canada  The colours will transform with the changes in the light and its reflection on the Serpentine Lake will be like an abstract painting. Work started in April to stack the 55-gallon barrels into their cut-off pyramid shape.   Christo was joined at the launch by former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg, chairman of the Serpentine Galleries. Christo and his wife Jeanne-Claude, who died in 2009, are known for such works as The Gates, a 2005 installation in New York's Central Park, and the wrapping of the Reichstag in Berlin.

title: kate middleton waited five years
story: NewsWhy Kate Middleton waited five years to go to Royal Ascot - but Meghan Markle is going straight awayKate Middleton made her Royal Ascot debut in 2016, five years after she married Prince William&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer13:28, 19 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailToday Meghan Markle will join her new in-laws for a day at the races at Royal Ascot. The new Duke and Duchess of Sussex have been invited by the Queen to watch this year's event from the royal box, and Meghan is expected to present the winning trophy. She's attending the popular event just four weeks after become a member of the royal family. However her sister-in-law the Duchess of Cambridge waited five long years after her wedding day before making her Ascot debut back in 2016.  It's not a case of not being invited, as Kate was apparently invited every year but turned it down. But she didn't turn it down because she couldn't be bothered or just didn't fancy an afternoon with the in-laws. According to Hello! magazine's royal expert Emily Nash, Kate and William were focusing on raising their young children. When Wills quit his job and the couple started taking on more royal duties, they began to attend. Meghan and Harry on the other hand were keen to hit the ground running straight after their wedding, and they actually postponed their wedding so they could start straight away.  So far she's attended a Buckingham Palace garden party and accompanied the Queen on a full day of official engagements in Cheshire. Kate first joined the rest of the royal gang at Royal Ascot for a very special year - the Queen's 90th birthday. She wore a stunning white lace Dolce &amp Gabbana for her debut with a matching fascinator. Her 2017 dress was very similar, resulting in lots of people thinking she had worn the same outfit twice.  However on closer inspection it was a different dress, this time from her old favourite Alexander McQueen. The dress appeared to be a modified version of the brand's lace mini dress, which was originally on sale for &pound4,463. This morning Kensingston Palace revealed Meghan and Harry will visit Ireland in July on their first official international trip as a married couple.

title: loughborough junction three graffiti artists
story: NewsLoughborough Junction: Three graffiti artists killed by train were 'taken too soon' but 'art will live on'Tributes have been paid on Instagram and Twitter to the three young men whose bodies were found on Monday morning - known in the street art scene as Lover, Kbag and Trip&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter10:55, 19 JUN 2018Updated11:18, 19 JUN 2018NewsThis picture was posted on Instagram with numerous posts saying 'RIP Trip' (Image: ukfrontline/Instagram)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTributes have been paid to the three graffiti artists killed when they were struck by a train in south London. The bodies of three young men were found near Loughborough Junction station just after 7.30am on Monday. The men, aged 19, 23 and 23, have not been formally identified but they have been named in the London street art scene by their tags of Lover, Kbag and Trip. One of the images posted on social media shows Trip climbing some scaffolding next to some graffiti on a wall. Today friends said they had been 'taken too soon' - but that their 'art will live on'. Several of the tributes posted online say 'Rest in Paint' (RIP). British Transport Police have not confirmed the three were graffiti artists but said that was 'one line of enquiry'. Spray cans were found near the bodies. Tributes have been left at Loughborough Station with someone spray painting a shutter 'RIP' with three hearts underneath.    Wellwishers also left three bottles of spray paint with the nozzles removed - in pink, yellow and orange. Fellow graffiti artists are repeating the mantra 'Rest in Paint' on social media sites. But former TfL board member Brian Cooke has sparked outrage for calling the men 'common scum'. In response to a BBC report on the incident Mr Cooke, from Beckenham, south London, tweeted: Why do BBC News keep referring to the guys killed at Loughborough Junction as graffiti 'artists' they are no such thing they are common scum and criminals who cost the railway millions and keep fares high.  His message prompted a furious response with one critic saying: 3 lives lost, undoubtedly a traumatised train driver... shame on you for such reckless and thoughtless comments and opinion on a tragedy spare a thought for their families before you type! Mr Cooke has now made his twitter profile private.   On the Real london graffiti page on Facebook a picture has been shared of the clear bag of evidence collected by police at the scene yesterday morning - which included spray cans - saying RIP Kbag - Lover - Trip.  Loughborough Junction is an elevated station managed by Thameslink and located on a line between Herne Hill and Elephant and Castle stations. It is near three other lines used by trains which do not stop at the station. The area is said to be a graffiti hotspot - with its proximity to Brixton and a trend in youngsters to try and get their tag on tricky-to-reach spots along the railway line. Investigators believe the tragedy took place in the early hours and are working to identify which train struck the men.

title: mum cleared biting womans finger
story: NewsMum cleared of biting woman's finger off says stress of trial caused her to miscarry twinsWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Louisa Jensen, 27, was accused of biting through the bone of 30-year-old Laura Gwin's finger in a fight in Kirkby last year&nbspShareByJenny Kirkham06:45, 19 JUN 2018Updated07:00, 19 JUN 2018NewsLouisa Jensen says she now suffers from PTSD following the trial (Image: LiverpoolEcho/ WS)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who was cleared of biting another woman's finger off in a row over rent says the stress of the trial caused her to miscarry her twins and ruined her life. Louisa Jenson admitted fighting with Laura Gwin but maintained that she did not bite her. Last week she was cleared of unlawful wounding. The 27-year-old said that although she was found not guilty, the ordeal of being arrested and the process of going through a trial caused her to lose her job, miscarry the twins she was pregnant with and suffer post traumatic stress disorder. Speaking to the Liverpool Echo after the trial Louisa said that she had went to Miss Gwin's home in October last year to discuss ongoing issues between them.  Kevin Slack, prosecuting, told the court the women had fallen out over rent arrears owed by Miss Gwin to Jensen's aunt, and comments made about each other to parents at their children's school. On the day of the incident Laura Gwin text Miss Jensen's aunt saying: “The sorriest thing (Jensen) will ever do is thinking she is so big and clever. I will rip her f****** head off when I see her.” Miss Jensen said that as their children attend the same school she was concerned that something would kick off in front of the kids and other parents at the school gates. She said: I didn't want it to keep getting worse, I was hoping to sort things out but it escalated really quickly. Both women then got into a fight in Miss Gwin's front garden before being separated by Laura Gwin's boyfriend. Miss Gwin, 30, lost almost the entire fingernail portion of the index finger on her left hand, including bone, and was left covered in blood after the incident on October 11 last year. Louisa, from Kirkby, walked out of Liverpool Crown Court on Friday after being cleared of unlawful wounding without intent by a jury, but has since said the ordeal has ruined her life. She said: I don't deny going to her house but I did not mean for it to get physical. After the fight I went straight to the police station to report it, but they told me to come back in an hour because they were busy.

title: one day tell everything dad
story: NewsDad left to bring up daughter alone after wife died while six months pregnant - but baby was delivered aliveEmmanuel Olubayo's wife of only eight months, Emma, died suddenly at their home in Leicestershire before the couple's baby was posthumously delivered&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAdrian Troughton06:28, 19 JUN 2018Updated09:35, 19 JUN 2018NewsWidower Emmanuel Olubayo will bring up his daughter alone (Image: Caters News Agency)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father has been left to bring up his daughter alone after his wife died while six months pregnant - but her baby was delivered alive. Emmanuel Olubayo could only watch helplessly as Emma, a nursing team leader, collapsed from an undetected heart defect and died in the home they shared in Leicestershire. Paramedics tried for an hour to resuscitate the 41-year-old before performing a rare posthumous delivery.  They carried out an emergency Caesarean section on the living room floor last November, Leicestershire Live reports.  The couple's baby girl Aretha was delivered alive then taken to hospital.  Emmanuel said he was shocked to become a father and a widower on the same day. The 35-year-old education consultant said: “It is hard and I don’t really know how I am coping as single dad but I am. “I have to be strong for Aretha. One day I will tell her all about her mother and how wonderful she was.” He said he believed his wife of eight months, whose heart suddenly stopped, had battled on to give their daughter Aretha the chance to live. Aretha was born 10 weeks prematurely and was taken to hospital where she was cared for by members of the team that Emma led – the critical care outreach team which covers Glenfield Hospital, Leicester Royal Infirmary and Leicester General Hospital.  Emmanuel, who was living in Birmingham, told how he and Emma fell in love after meeting in an internet dating chat room. “I knew when I started chatting to Emma online that she was special, he said. We had an immediate connection. “We got on really well and arranged to meet after three weeks chatting.” The pair had their first date at the Parcel Yard pub in Leicester in May 2016.  Emmanuel said: “I caught a train after work and we met at about 7pm. “We did not want the night to end and I caught the last train home to Birmingham. “The evening had flown by and we talked about everything and nothing. “We could not wait to see each other and were in contact all the time from that night on. “it was as if we were meant to be together.” The romance blossomed as Emma travelled to Birmingham and Emmanuel came to Leicester to see each other. In December 2016 – seven months after they first chatted online – Emmanuel popped the question. “We were out for meal in Birmingham when I got down on one knee in the restaurant, he said. “I gave Emma a sapphire ring and asked her to marry me. “She said yes and was ecstatic. Everyone cheered. It was beautiful.” The pair married in Birmingham in April 2017.  Within a month Emma was pregnant. Emmanuel said: “We were both delighted that we were pregnant so quickly. “Everything was going so well. It was great and we were making plans for the future. We wanted a couple of children. “We did not want to know what sex the baby was. We wanted it to be a surprise. “It was fun choosing names for a boy and for a girl.” Aretha was taken to hospital and was finally allowed home a month before her due date.  More than 650 people attended Emma’s funeral and friends have set up an online fund-raising page for Emmanuel and Aretha.  Clair Ripley, who set up the fund, said online: “Emma was a highly regarded nurse at University Hospitals of Leicester and was the driving force behind the Critical Care Outreach and Sepsis Teams. “Some of you may be aware and some of you may not, but unfortunately on November 26 2017, Emma suddenly passed away. “She was so very loved as a wife, daughter, sister, auntie, friend and colleague.

title: property giant wants residents pay
story: NewsProperty giant wants residents to pay £10,000 each to remove Grenfell Tower-like claddingHundreds of Manchester city centre residents are being dragged through the courts by Pemberstone - one year on from the Grenfell Tower tragedy&nbspShareByJennifer Williams11:09, 19 JUN 2018NewsThe group of residents are locked in a tribunal over the money and fear they will be forced to cough up (Image: Manchester Evening News)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA property giant is dragging hundreds of city centre residents through the courts to force &pound10,000 each out of them for the removal of dangerous Grenfell-style cladding. One year on from the tower block tragedy, more than 300 leaseholders at Vallea Court and Cypress Place in the Green Quarter, Manchester, have been arguing their case at a tribunal. Their freeholder, the investor Pemberstone, has issued them with a demand for &pound3m out of the blue. That was the result of investigations carried out in the wake of the London blaze, which found the same dangerously flammable material had been used on their blocks. After the leaseholders refused to pay, Pemberstone launched legal action against them - which saw residents crowd-fund enough money to pay for legal advice, but still unable to fund a lawyer for the hearing. Fran Reddington, 33, says the community has had no help from the council, the mayor’s office, the government or anyone else, adding that they have effectively been left to fend for themselves.  “The hardest thing for us is that we have not really had any support from anybody,” she said. “We got the official letters from the management company but then we got hit by these notices and we didn’t really know what to do. “Luckily we have got quite a strong community and set up this Facebook group to see what we could do together. So that’s how we got the crowdfunding.  We didn’t have the option of a lawyer though and just had to fight for ourselves. “It’s so stressful and we’ve just been left. The worst thing is that we’re just being ignored.” The two Green Quarter blocks, which are managed by Living City, were built by international development giant Lend Lease. In recent years the freehold has been sold on to Pemberstone, a property investment giant that owns residential and commercial buildings across the country, which argues that under the terms of their leases the residents should pay for any remedial works themselves.  However a copy of one introduction letter sent by Lend Lease to a purchaser - who had bought their flat directly from them - states that ‘Lend Lease will undertake, at our expense, to complete any accepted defect that has arisen as a result of either faulty materials or defective workmanship’. Nevertheless while the buildings are understood to still be under warranty, residents have so far also been unable to claim costs for removing and replacing the cladding through insurance - and they say Lend Lease has been silent on the issue. Residents have also noted that the developer, states in its corporate vision that ‘companies must start justifying their worth to society, with greater emphasis placed on environmental and social impact rather than straight economics’. Marketing consultant Katie Kelly bought her flat from the developer four years ago. “Not only are big businesses failing to do the right thing, they are happily putting over 300 people’s lives at risk,” she said.  “The way the whole situation has been handled, from taking us to a tribunal which we will likely have to pay for, to taking over a year to even begin work to make our homes safe, is crazy.   “I can’t understand how nobody from these businesses feels responsible.”  Leaseholders say they have no idea what will happen if they lose the tribunal and are left literally unable to pay the money. Lucy Powell, MP for next-door Manchester Central, has been dealing with a number of such cases in the city over the past year, including a similar dispute at the Chips building in New Islington. A few weeks ago housing minister Dominic Raab responded to an inquiry from her on the issue, reiterating that private sector companies should ‘do the right thing’ and not pass the costs on to leaseholders. However his letter does not outline any government plans to force the hand of those who will not, adding that ministers are keeping the situation ‘under review’.  Lucy Powell said that one year on from Grenfell blaze, on June 14 last year, the government’s position was ‘not good enough’. “I have been helping lots of residents who are concerned about fire safety – particularly in private blocks, she added. “In many cases they are also worried about being forced to pay huge sums to make their buildings safe. “In a recent reply I received from the government I was told that the government were urging companies not to pass costs on to leaseholders but this is not good enough.  “People who bought their homes in good faith now find that they may not be safe and on top of their worries, they are often being asked to pay large sums of money to put that right.” One year on, the government is ‘nowhere near’ sorting out the implications of Grenfell for the private housing sector, she added. The tribunal is expected to take around six weeks to report back.  A spokesperson for Pemberstone said: “The tribunal is a well established forum to which either landlords or leaseholders can apply to establish clarity on an issue that affects the management of a residential building and its service charge.  “Tribunals are independent and are widely used within the residential property sector. They are particularly appropriate for large schemes like this where there are 345 apartment owners, some of whom are investors located overseas.   “We believe an independent decision from a tribunal would be in the best interests for all concerned and should allow us to establish a clear way forward.  “Our property managers Livingcity are in regular contact with apartment owners and have been providing regular updates.  “Over the past year they have sent out nine letters to all leaseholders explaining the latest position and have issued responses to at least 78 individual enquiries.  “They have an office on site and a web portal on which they post information.  “They also hold regular residents’ meetings including one in February attended by over 100 individuals.

title: royal ascot 2018 meghan markle
story: NewsRoyal Ascot 2018: Glamorous racegoers face armed police and sniffer dogs amid tight security on first day of sporting eventSecurity was out in force ahead of a visit from The Duke and Duchess of Sussex, who will join The Queen and present the winning trophy for the St James' Palace Stakes&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop11:25, 19 JUN 2018Updated13:18, 19 JUN 2018NewsLadies mingle with armed officers at today's event (Image: David Dyson)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds of glamorous racegoers were met by sniffer dogs and armed police as they arrived to tight security on the first day of Royal Ascot 2018. Punters posed for the cameras with ladies dressed in floral outfits and brightly coloured fascinators and gents sporting top hats and elegant suits. Many faced breathalyser tests and bag searches as organisers seek to clamp down on anti-social behaviour this year. There has also been a crackdown on beer sales and an increased stewarding presence. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will join the Queen at the huge sporting event later today where they are expected to present the winning trophy for the St James' Palace Stakes at 4.20pm. It's believed The Queen has also invited the newlyweds to join her in the royal box this week at the Berkshire race course.  A carriage procession, with The Queen at its head, signals the start of each day of the event, and Harry and Meghan could be part of the spectacle. Ahead of the big race at 3.40pm racegoers poured into the venue dressed to the nines. Kelly Brooke was among the crowd, sporting a football themed hat from Ladbrokes to celebrate England’s football hopes. The star of the bookmaker’s latest racing ad campaign, says: “I really want to show my support for the Three Lions and by wearing this gorgeous Ladbrokes hat designed by Ilda Di Vico, I think I have done just that.”   The hat features a Bobby Moore figure holding aloft a Jules Rimet trophy and was designed by milliner Ilda Di Vico. Royal Ascot is renowned for its strict dress code and this year men must wear socks or risk being turned away from the famous race meet which is one of the highlights of the social calendar. With the UK having enjoyed good weather in the past few months the fashion for wearing shoes without socks may have crept into Royal Ascot. This year's visitors sported an array of fashionable outfits - with ladies arriving in pastel pencil dress, brightly coloured stripy skirts and even a four of diamonds inspired dress.  Rupert Adams from William Hill said: Ascot have tightened up the dress code for the royal meeting and many of the millennial generation might not even own socks. Punters traditionally have a bet on the colour of the Queen's hat with blue the favourite with bookies at the moment for the first day. Jessica Bridge of Ladbrokes said: Punters reckon Her Majesty will opt for a trusty shade of blue on the opening day of the Royal meeting. Last year there was a massive gamble on the Queen wearing blue as she wore blue to the state opening of Parliament before travelling to Royal Ascot, but she changed into another coloured outfit for the race meet.  The Queen spoke about her fondness for Royal Ascot in her foreword for the official programme: My family and I greatly look forward to Royal Ascot. As the royal meeting has evolved in recent times, it remains one of Britain's finest sporting occasions with 300,000 racegoers enjoying the unique heritage of Royal Ascot every year, and many more people watching at home. Tradition and innovation sit comfortably together, over five days of racing. International competition is a compelling feature in the modern era, and it is always a delight to welcome horses and jockeys from around the world to this wonderful racecourse.

title: size 32 mum who binged
story: NewsSize-32 mum who binged on 8,000 calories a day and feared she was eating herself to death loses 18stDawn Dawson reached nearly 30st after gorging on two takeaways, four bacon sandwiches and two litres of fizzy pop every day - but that all changed after her dad's death&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByChristina Wood10:40, 19 JUN 2018NewsDawn Dawson pictured on her wedding day (Image: Lorna Taylor Photography/Fortitu)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA size-32 mum who feared for her life after an 8,000-calorie-a-day diet has now lost a staggering 18st.  Dawn Dawson weighed 28st 9lbs at her biggest after gorging on two takeaways, four bacon sandwiches and two litres of fizzy pop every day.  The 38-year-old, who now weighs 10st 9lbs, ate so much that she developed type 2 diabetes, a high cholesterol level and regularly took painkillers to help with the aches and pains that piling on the pounds had caused. However, she decided to make a change when her 61-year-old dad Steve Hadley passed away in November 2014 due to cancer, which Dawn believes was triggered by obesity.  The mum-of-two worried she would be next and ditched her junk food addiction and lost 6st 7lbs by herself before joining Slimming World in August 2015 for extra support.   By November 2017, Dawn had completed her amazing weight loss and dropped down to an incredible size 10 and now no longer has to take any form of medication. Dawn, from Chester-Le-Street, in County Durham, said: “Losing my dad gave me a massive kick up the backside. I thought if I don’t stop eating, I’m going to die. “I often think to myself, ‘how didn’t I end up in a serious state?’ It is a mystery to me. It is a scary thought. I don’t know how I carried on doing that for so long. “I would eat until it hurt. I used to secret snack two or three times a day, just to make myself feel full. I would just eat anything that was put in front of me. It was just pure greed. “I didn’t want to join my dad. I didn’t want to leave my children. I would have ended up in serious trouble. I wanted to save my life and that is what I’ve done.  “I had been big all of my life but I’m not that person anymore. I have got my life to live now and I’m going to live it.” The full-time carer to her mum Carol Hadley, 60, revealed that because of her ballooning dress size, she couldn’t even walk to the top of her street without getting out of breath. Dawn said: “It restricted me from doing so much. I was terrified of going out before. I was embarrassed to just go to the park with my kids [Daniel, 5 and Amelia, 3] but now I can even go on the rides. “It is a lot easier with my kids now. They have a mum now. My husband was doing everything with them before. I am so much more involved.” After losing the weight, Dawn was left with a lot of excess skin but in March this year she had it surgically removed to complete her transformation.

title: theres something very wrong stamp
story: NewsPrincess Diana and Prince Charles wedding stamp causes stir after royal fans spot something very wrong with itThe stamp, which was released to celebrate their marriage in 1981, has resurfaced after people noticed something odd&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJoshua BarrieZoe ForseyAudience Writer07:55, 19 JUN 2018Updated08:44, 19 JUN 2018NewsOh dear (Image: Royal Mail)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn old stamp released to mark Princess Charles and Princess Diana's wedding is causing a bit of a stir decades after it was revealed. Royal fans have noticed something very odd about the 25p stamp, which is dated July 29, 1981. It shows the couple standing next to each other smiling happily as they prepare for their special day. But eagle-eyed fan Philip Cohen made an interesting observation about the picture - their height.    In the photo Prince Charles seems to be a whole head taller than his wife. But in reality the couple were actually the same height - 1.78m, which is just under 5ft 9.  A quick Google of the pair and you'll see many like it. Charles is visibly 'taller' in formal photographs, particularly headshots. However, when the two were snapped walking around, it's clear the stamp isn't really a reasonable representation. People have a few ideas as to why Charles appears so much taller than Diana.

title: woman left incurable leg condition
story: NewsWoman left with incurable leg condition where one leg swells twice the size of other after cancer ordealCalley Bingham is learning to live with an incurable leg condition after undergoing treatment for cancer&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByClaire Violette HerbauxStewart Carr11:19, 19 JUN 2018Updated11:23, 19 JUN 2018NewsCalley Bingham was diagnosed with cervical cancer at just 25 (Image: Somerset Live WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young woman who survived cancer after being diagnosed at 25 has been left with a incurable leg condition. Calley Bingham was diagnosed with cervical cancer just four months after giving birth to her third child. After a long ordeal of surgery and therapies, Calley, now aged 27, overcame cancer but she has been left with lymphoedema, a condition where one of her legs swells up to almost twice the size of the other. Lymphoedema affects around 200,000 people in the UK, and Calley is determined to provide support through her new charity.   How to avoid deep vein thrombosis on a long flight - and other issues you face on a plane   The young woman from Meare, near Glastonbury, told Somerset Live : When I was diagnosed with cervical cancer my world fell apart. In the very beginning we all held our breath and prayed.  At a stage 1B2 - I was cureable. I underwent a 7.5 hour operation to remove my womb, cervix, fallopian tubes and part of my vagina and my pelvic lymph nodes. Then I had to go through six weeks of chemo-radiation and two lots of brachytherapy. I was grateful to be alive.   Mum sues hospital after waking up with permanent breast implants after her double mastectomy  I knew all this could cause lymphoedema, but there was no guarantee and I guess, like everyone else, you just assume it won't be you it happens to, or hope, at least. It started off with mild swelling but got worse. I was diagnosed with lymphoedema in my inner thigh in January last year and there is no chance of a cure. My experience with the condition has been painful - physically and mentally draining. It has changed the way I see myself and others see me. It changed the clothes and shoes I can wear and the amount of exercise I'm able to do. The only treatment available includes Manual Lymphatic Drainage (MLD) massage, which she travels to Taunton for weekly, and compression stockings, which she has to wear every day.   Mum 'too ashamed to go outside' after her eyes swelled shut after eyebrow tint  Having two legs completely different sizes brings about day-to-day problems for the young mum, especially as retailers don't cater for people with this or similar condition. Calley explains how shopping for clothes has become difficult: In the year and a half that I have had lymphoedema, my leg and foot have nearly doubled in size. Currently I carry four litres more fluid in my left leg and it is 40 per cent bigger than my right. Bandaging to reduce the size of my leg was unsuccessful and I have now been put forward for lymph assist treatment. One of the biggest things for me is that I couldn't just buy some Nikes or something young and in fashion to wear. Retailers don't provide odd pairs. The only shoes I am able to find that are comfortable and fit are more suitable for older people to be honest. I got in contact with Nike and various other shoe brands only to be told they didn't have a procedure to sell me a pair of odd shoes. Clarks said they did sell odd pairs but I'd have to pay more than standard price. And again their styles aren't ones I would pick. I feel like people stare enough. I tend to wear leggings or stretchy jeggings as they stretch over the big leg, but I am having issues with them so my mum is making me lighter clothes for the summer. Inspired by her experience of dealing with retailers, Calley has made it her mission to help people with the same problem.
